entry.title: Combined summary - Some PR preparation
entry.summary: Bitcoin experienced a minor bug that caused transaction delays of a few hours, but the coins were safe and difficult to exploit. However, the incident received negative attention, and it was suggested that preparing PR comments in advance could help mitigate any inaccurate or exaggerated reporting.There were reports of circulating double-spends during a blockchain fork, and while it was confirmed that only seven out of 430 transactions were true double spends, it was essential to confirm that no one had been ripped off. The incident received media attention due to Bitcoin's rising popularity at the time, and there were concerns about the potential negative impact on the currency. There were also discussions around the risks involved in a rejected block and the potential for conflicts in both chains.During a recent Bitcoin test, there was a discussion around the possibility of any double-spend attempts. Some individuals believed that it is unlikely such an attempt was made, while others argued that the risk was real and should not be downplayed. However, many people agreed that the test was successful and credit goes to everyone who contributed to it. One participant in the discussion suggested contacting larger payment processors might be necessary, as some individuals could have been scammed even with standard precautions.In an email exchange, Luke-Jr expressed concern about the risk of double-spending during a brief period when transactions could have received up to N confirmations and then still been reversed. There was a possibility that people trying to buy/sell on OTC could have been scammed even by taking standard precautions. However, another participant in the exchange argued that the risk was not as great as it appeared because any valid transactions hitting the network would get added to everyone's memory pool and mined in both chains.Thus all nodes would still reject double-spend attempts. Majority mining power on one of the chains was required, and both had non-negligible computing power on them, so double-spending still required an exceptional amount of resources, just not the normal 50% that is normally needed. It required at least 10%, which limited the number of potential attackers. In addition, a victim needed to be found that hadn't seen the alert, was willing to execute a large transaction, and was on the wrong side of the chain. This made the attack outside the scope of regular users.Overall, it was important to address potential risks and ensure the safety and security of Bitcoin transactions, despite any blowback or negative attention that may arise from incidents. Thorough testing and addressing potential risks were essential for the safety and security of Bitcoin transactions.
